history.content: Unfortunately, this sounds like a campus level inquiry.

children.subject:
Thank you for your response, professor.

I believe 169 is the only course taught on edX by the department now.

In high school, I took the edX version of CS188 - it was a fantastic class. When I went back on the edX site for that original course, I was disappointed to find out it had been replaced by a Columbia equivalent, which was much drier and definitely not as good as the one taught as the one taught by Prof Abbeel and Prof Klein.

A lot of the original courses now have been closed for enrollment (i.e. even old materials have been closed off to the public), which was the reason for my question.

188 got me excited about EECS, and I just wanted to see more of that :)

I'd suggest contacting the instructor of the EdX course you're interested in, if you want to know whether the course will be opened up again.  Instructors opt into teaching a course on EdX if they're excited about it, so there might not be any global answer that applies to every course.

I don't know what has stopped and what hasn't.  I wouldn't be surprised if the CS 169-based one is still open or will be available again.  I'm not sure it's accurate to say that Berkeley isn't offering any CS courses on EdX.  I know of at least one CS course planned to be offered on EdX in the not-too-distant future.
I think Professor Armando Fox is very involved around this, you should email him.

history.content:
In 2014, Berkeley ran a couple of classes on edX (the public one, not edge), including EE40, CS169, EECS149, CS188, and an entirely original Data Science course that taught Apache Spark.

I'm wondering what happened to these efforts? Seeing many classes remain webcasted and much of the content online, I think Berkeley could help a great deal of people learn material if they can't get into a class (waitlist etc) and others who want to enter EECS.

No pressure to actually begin these efforts again, I'm just wondering why they stopped. Thanks.
history.subject: What happened to Berkeley's edX intitiatives?
